trans-unit.source: Review and select the content you want to include in your report. Once completed, you can block or mute accounts, hide replies, or save and share your report
Search and filter to find the comments you want to add to your report.
Displays the search bar, and menus for filtering by time (default since yesterday), harmful categories (5 selected by default), and more filter options (none selected by default).
Comments are blurred by default. Use this setting to indicate what type of content you want to see.
Displays the comment blur button toggle option, set to hidden by default
See a limited number of comments per page.
Displays the pagination buttons, showing which comments are visible on this page and the total number of comments.
No comments found for the current filters
Error loading comments. Please try again.
View comment details and select which comments to include in your report. Your work will be saved if you leave and come back.

Displays the comment card, which includes info on how likely harmful the comment is, the comment's popularity, the time it was posted, and comment text and other metadata. It can be expanded to show more details about toxicity model scores and engagement metrics for this comment.

Need help? FeedShield offers a virtual helpline for people facing online harassment to talk to trained crisis counsellors, who will help connect users with local experts or support organisations. The helpline is run by a trauma counselling CSO based, Mental 360, in Kenya, and can currently only support callers in English. FeedShield will add partners who can assist in other international languages such as Arabic and French in 2023.
Counsellors will treat your call as confidential, protecting all your personal information, and will only share your details with our other support teams if you explicitly request them to in writing.

*Though a counselling service, the virtual helpline is not an emergency service. If you are in imminent danger, if someone is threatening you with physical violence online or it escalates, take the following steps to ensure your safety:
Save screengrabs in case threatening tweets get deleted
Do not engage any further with the person that is threatening you
Why does it only work on Twitter?
Can it detect harmful images and videos?
How do I learn about future opportunities?

FeedShield helps you to take back control of your Twitter feed. It is a free web application designed for human rights defenders, such as journalists and activists, but open for anyone to use. It syncs with the user’s Twitter account, automatically recognising and flagging harmful comments from the last one week. The resulting analysis helps users limit their exposure to abusive content, by allowing them to block, mute or save comments at scale. It also allows users to create reports to store or share with investigators or other watchdogs as needed. FeedShield further helps users connect with allies, from crisis counsellors on a dedicated helpline, to local experts or support organisations.

Human rights defenders are increasingly being targeted by online trolls, who often coordinate their attacks. Women journalists, activists and public leaders are being especially targeted by toxic campaigns that seek to flood their victim’s social feeds with demeaning or threatening content as a way of drowning out or silencing women’s voices. The victims have, up until now, had no easy way to analyse the abuse or collect the evidence. FeedShield aims to change that by offering a combination of digital tools and investigative support. Get more information about why, in the launch announcement here.

FeedShield is an initiative of Africas largest network of civic technology and digital democracy labs, Code for Africa. CfA has full-time staff/labs in 21 African countries that work in support of networks of watchdog media, human rights defending CSOs, and progressive development agencies. CfA has partnered with Googles Jigsaw team to customise its Harassment Manager toolkit for African conditions. The toolkit also includes resources created by a global coalition of other civic organisations who have developed support materials, ranging from tipsheets and training courses, to campaign materials and other complementary tools. Read more about the resources here.

FeedShield is designed for frontline human rights defenders, such as journalists and activists. CfA is also emphasising support for women thought-leaders who are being targeted online. However, the tool is free to use by anyone, and CfA will consider support requests regardless of users' profession or gender.

Once you’ve logged on to your dashboard through your Twitter account, FeedShield rates each tweet that mentions you within the last one week and assigns each one a toxicity score based on how likely they are to be harmful. You can then view or hide comments within FeedShield, curate them into reports and even share them with other parties that can support you deal with the abuse. You can also export your report and save it either on Google Drive or locally by downloading a PDF, printing a copy, or saving a CSV file without notifying the abusers. FeedShield won't post anything on your behalf. Find out more in this tutorial here.

Neither CfA nor Jigsaw will access any of the personal data within your Twitter account. No personal data is stored within the tool - your dashboard is wiped each time you finish a session. Only draft reports - designed to be downloaded and shared with third parties by you alone – are temporarily stored in the tool. Once completed, the report will be deleted from FeedShield. Read our detailed privacy policy here.

Google’s Jigsaw and Twitter partnered in 2020 to pioneer ways to tackle the surging tide of online harassment targeting journalists and activists across the world. The resulting technology that underpins FeedShield uses Google’s Perspective API and Twitter’s API to prove it is possible to give social media users ways to manage their exposure to online abuse. CfA and its partners welcome any opportunities to grow this cross-sector collaboration and expand the technology to other platforms, making it more accessible to human rights defenders around the world. Find the open source code here.

Perspective, the free API powering FeedShield, can detect harmful content in multiple languages, however Feedshield will initially support English at launch. CfA will launch Arabic and French versions of FeedShield in 2023, and is working with Jigsaw to improve Perspective’s detection in indigenous African languages.
FeedShield has been designed to identify and filter abusive words and phrases, rather than images and videos.
FeedShield does not currently identify abusive DMs. It only analyses public Tweets and comments.

FeedShield is a pilot project. We would therefore love to hear your feedback, and answer any questions not covered by these FAQs. Please email feedshield@codeforafrica.org and our team will get back to you as quickly as possible. This email address is not monitored 24/7 and should not be used to contact CfA for urgent assistance with any harassment. If you need urgent help, use the helpline here

The FeedShield team will be offering regular training, and other material and technical support to institutional partners. We will be also offering research fellowships to better understand how online trolls are coordinating their harassment of women in particular.If you are interested in keeping updated, email feedshield@codeforafrica.org with a request to be added to our community list.
What is the timeframe for which I can create a report on my Tweets using Feedshield?
FeedShield allows you to generate reports on tweets that have been live within the most recent 7 days.

Trolls use online violence to silence civic watchdogs. FeedShield is a free tool powered by Jigsaw, using its Harassment Manager toolkit, and implemented by Code for Africa (CfA) to help Twitter users document and manage online harassment and abuse.

Machine learning is the processs of using computers to learn based on data. This tool uses machine learning developed by Perspective API, which has been tested and trained to score comments based on their possible impact.
based on their likeliness of containing
Harmful content is rude, disrespectful, or unreasonable content that is likely to make you leave a discussion. We use this definition as a guideline when grouping and scoring comments.
Start a report with grouped comments
Comments are grouped based on priority. Use these groups to start building a report.
Already know what you're looking for?
These results are categorised by machine learning based on their likeliness of containing harmful content.
Use the tool to flag online harrasment and collect evidence about the abuse
A man with a cap stands and writes on a very large document hanging on a wall. There are geometric shapes with varying textures on the ground
The tool will categorise comments based on their likeliness of containing harmful content.
A woman placing a huge, person-sized document in a similarly huge folder.
Document the evidence and take action

Create a report. Select the comments to be included in your report. Reports can be downloaded and shared with third parties as needed. You can also block or mute accounts and hide replies, without having to review the harmful content
A woman walks among geometric shapes strewn about the floor. She is holding a large circular shape in her arm.
Loading times will vary depending on how many comments you have
comments loaded and more to come
Do you want to take an active role in combating online abuse? Join us!
Do trolls invade your timeline all too often? Want to filter them out before you read them?
Do you want to take an active role in combating coordinated online abuse that targets African women journalists, election candidates or other human rights defenders ?

Trolls often hide behind fake accounts (what we call sock-puppets) or rely on misleading claims to smear or attack human rights defenders. CfA has Africa’s largest teams working to debunk disinformation and expose the hidden networks coordinating the abuse. Here’s how they can help you:

CfA’s PesaCheck is the continent’s largest fact-checking newsroom, with full-time researchers in 14 African countries. It is an accredited member of the IFCN (International Fact Checking Network), and adheres to a strict ethical code. PesaCheck’s fact-checks are published by a wide network of partner media across Africa, and are also used by social media platforms such as Facebook, Instagram and TikTok to combat toxic content. Facebook alone uses PesaCheck debunks to label over two million posts per year as harmful or misleading content. PesaCheck may help research and debunk any misleading claims being used to target or harass you, if the claims meet PesaCheck’s eligibility criteria.

CfA’s iLAB at the African Network of Centres for Investigative Reporting (ANCIR) work alongside PesaCheck, as the continent’s largest network of forensic analysts who ‘connect the dots’. They do this by exposing the coordinated networks behind the abuse, mapping the influencers, diagnosing the techniques they use, and tracking the narratives. Their analyses help watchdog organisations determine whether the social media platform policies have been iolated, or whether other safeguards against amplified hate speech and toxic content have been violated. iLAB’ss dossiers serve as evidence for investigative media, and contribute to remedial action by both platforms and regulators who take down or de-platform entire networks of inauthentic accounts on social media.

Are you convinced that the harassment targeting you is part of a coordinated campaign, or is being amplified by an inauthentic network? Complete the simple form below so that we can help verify whether our teams are able to help. You will need to first use the FeedShield tool to analyse the harassment, and must download both the resulting PDF report and CSV (spreadsheet) dataset. Share as much extra information as you can on the form, and tell us why you think there might be a network of trolls or other coordination behind the abuse. Also tell us why you think you are being targeted, and by who. Be sure to share your contact information, so our team can get back to you.
Your report will update as you add comments. Visit this page to preview comments and add context for your report.
Displays the continue button, with a shopping cart icon indicating how many comments are currently in the report.
Unfollow, mute and block toxic content. Take back control of your online experience with FeedShield.

Women journalists and other public figures in Africa are routinely targeted in coordinated attacks by online trolls. Trolls flood their target's social feeds with demeaning or threatening content as a way of drowning out or silencing women's voices on sensitive topics.
FeedShield is an online toolkit to help human rights defenders turn the tide, by documenting the abuse and unmasking the trolls.
Document the evidence, unmask the trolls
Find out how to use FeedShield to flag abusive content targeting you, so you can report the abuse to the platforms or get our forensic investigators to track the culprits.

FeedShield is building a network of allies. Our fact-checkers (Africa’s largest network) and forensic investigators are also on standby to help you debunk allegations or expose the puppet-masters behind smear campaigns.
Contact an expert crisis counselling professional trained to connect you to local appropriate industry bodies or support agencies and ensure incidents are appropriately addressed

Do you want to connect with human rights defending organisations who are helping fight against online harassment? FeedShield is part of an international coalition of campaigning CSOs and watchdog media industry organisations who are building resources, training champions, and helping support people targeted by trolls.
Do you want to take an active role in combating online abuse? Are you interested in being one of the first users of the FeedShield tool? Are there other ways you see yourself working with us?

FeedShield syncs with your Twitter account and uses machine learning technology to identify abusive comments. The tool rates each comment with a toxicity score and lets you take action - by muting or blocking accounts in bulk - without having to read the abusive messages. While all comments are automatically hidden, you can unhide them if you want to.
You can also collate harmful comments into a single report. This report can be downloaded and shared with Twitter and other trusted third parties as needed.

Abusive accounts will not know that they have been featured in a report. No third party - including Code for Africa and Twitter - will be able to access any of the reports you create, unless shared directly with them. Draft reports are temporarily stored in the tool to enable you to complete them. Once downloaded or abandoned, the report will be deleted from FeedShield.

Yes, your data is kept private when you use FeedShield. We only collect essential information such as your name and email address, and we will never share your personal data with third parties without your consent. We only use your personal data for the purpose for which it was collected.
What languages does the tool work with?
The FeedShield Tool is currently available in English. We are working on French and Arabic languages, so please check back soon for updates.
